slideInfo.title: Allusion: Reference to Literature, Art, or History

pButton.popInfo:
Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., alluding to Amos 5:24 in “I Have a Dream”:
“No, no, we are not satisfied, and we will not be satisfied until justice rolls down like waters, and righteousness like a mighty stream.”

Examples of book titles that allude to Shakespeare’s works:
Brave New World (“Oh brave new world that has such people in it!” —From The Tempest)
The Dogs of War (“Cry, ‘havoc!’, and let slip the dogs of war.” —From Julius Caesar)

How many times have you read about or listened to a song about a woman with a mysterious smile? Those are allusions to Leonardo da Vince’s Mona Lisa. Other allusions to the Mona Lisa are not as easy to spot, such as this line in Kurt Vonnegut’s Slaughterhouse Five: “Billy was helped to his feet by the lovely boy, by the heavenly androgyne.”
